# 總裁報告

2020年可謂是超乎想像的一年。

新冠病毒疫情肆虐全球，令人措手不及，世界各地的經濟活動幾乎陷於停頓。在疫情的打擊下，香港經濟繼2019年後連續第二年收縮，本地生產總值錄得有紀錄以來的最大跌幅。失業率飆升至16年高位，部分行業尤其受到重創。

然而，困境往往是展現我們實力的時候。儘管面對重重挑戰，香港的貨幣及銀行體系再次成功抵禦衝擊。這一切絕非偶然，而是我們多年來一直奉行審慎政策的成果。

復甦前路難望平坦。即使各地央行及政府都全力支持經濟，但前景仍充滿不確定性，包括央行的貨幣政策立場、疫苗接種計劃的進展，以及長期低息環境的潛在影響。另一方面，地緣政治緊張局勢變化不斷，令宏觀形勢更添變數。

縱使面對如此不明朗的形勢，金管局會繼續緊守崗位，維持貨幣及金融穩定，締造有利經濟復甦的環境。與此同時，在不斷演變的銀行及金融業大環境下，我們亦會致力把握機會，提升香港作為全球金融樞紐的競爭力。

# 貨幣及金融穩定：堅穩如昔

聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）在2020年繼續暢順有序地運作。聯匯制度自1983年實施至今，渡過一次又一次的難關，充分展現出抵禦衝擊的能力。儘管面對疫情及波動的宏觀經濟環境，年內港元匯率一直保持平穩。強方兌換保證合共被觸發85次，累計資金流入約3,835億港元。

聯匯制度得以維持穩健，全賴多年來所建立的穩固根基。正如國際貨幣基金組織在其《2020年對外部門報告》中的總結指出，聯匯制度的公信力建基於具高透明度的運作規則、充裕的財政及外匯儲備、穩健的金融監管、靈活的經濟及審慎的財政制度。同時，金管局透過與業界緊密聯繫，以及透過傳統及社交媒體與公眾有效溝通，迅速澄清謠言，並適時提供有關事實與數據的最新資訊。金管局亦利用最新的科技與數據分析技術，繼續提升監察能力，以靈活應對最新市況及新出現的風險。

雖然疫情對經濟造成沉重壓力，但銀行體系維持穩健，資本及流動資金充裕。於2020年底，本地銀行的資本充足比率為20.7%，遠高於國際最低要求的8%。大型銀行的平均流動性覆蓋比率亦遠高於法定最低要求的100%，於2020年第4季達到155.1%。受疫情影響，銀行的資產質素略為轉差，特定分類貸款比率於2020年底上升至0.9%，但仍屬穩健並遠低於自2000年以來的長期平均水平1.8%。

# 銀行體系：經濟命脈

銀行體系在經濟與社會中扮演重要的金融中介角色。年內金管局一方面繼續重點監管銀行的信用及流動性風險，另一方面亦密切留意疫情對銀行營運的影響，並採取多項措施，確保銀行體系能繼續提供基本服務，以及提供貸款支持經濟。金管局在3月下調逆周期緩衝資本比率100基點至1%，又在4月調低監管儲備水平。這些措施為銀行體系合共釋放約1萬億港元的借貸空間。

我們深知中小企在當前的經濟環境下或會面對資金周轉壓力。因此，金管局聯同我們在2019年成立的銀行業中小企貸款協調機制推出多輪紓困措施，包括「預先批核還息不還本」計劃，將合資格企業的所有貸款本金還款延期6個月。截至2020年底，銀行共批出超過58,000宗貸款展期及其他支援措施的個案，涉資超過7,400億港元。鑑於疫情反覆，金管局因應情況將「預先批核還息不還本」計劃展期，並於2021年3月將計劃延長至2021年10月底。香港按揭證券有限公司亦在其中小企融資擔保計劃下推出「百分百擔保特惠貸款」，以紓緩中小企支付僱員薪金及租金的負擔。截至2020年底，共批出超過25,000宗申請，涉資約400億港元。該計劃在2021年第1季作出優化，申請期限亦延長至2021年12月31日。年內銀行亦批出超過28,000宗紓困措施申請，協助個人客戶的資金周轉，涉資440億港元。銀行業同心協力，支持企業及個人客戶，共渡時艱，實在令人鼓舞。

與此同時，金管局繼續推動銀行業加強普及金融與實踐「以客為本」的文化。我們進一步鼓勵銀行格外留意有需要的客戶，並與銀行分享多方面的良好做法，包括為智障人士提供銀行服務，以及提供更多無障礙及方便易用的銀行服務。

隨着科技長足發展，銀行業的經營環境亦急速轉變。因此，金管局的工作不僅限於應對當前的挑戰，亦要放眼未來，擴大人才庫，以配合銀行業的日後發展。我們與香港銀行公會及香港銀行學會聯合展開「提升未來銀行業人才的專業能力」研究計劃，評估銀行業未來幾年的潛在人才缺口，並為銀行規劃清晰的路線圖，以期未雨綢繆，改善人才供應的情況。我們又推出「銀行業人才起動計劃」，為本地大學的應屆畢業生提供為期6個月的實習機會及銀行業相關的特定培訓，藉以為業界培育人才。在本港勞工市場的嚴峻時期推出此計劃，亦正好為有志加入銀行業的年青人提供機會。

# 國際金融中心地位：無懼挑戰

為履行金管局其中一項重要職責，協助鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，我們的未來規劃涵蓋銀行體系以至整個金融體系，旨在讓香港在不斷演變的金融環境中能夠保持作為國際金融中心的競爭力。在疫情期間，我們仍然穩步推進這些工作，並在幾個重點範疇積極開拓新機遇，以充分把握新趨勢及轉變的契機。

# 推動綠色金融，締造更可持續的未來

第一個範疇是推動綠色及可持續金融。自2019年5月推出分三階段進行的措施以來，相關工作已取得理想進展。我們在2020年完成對47間銀行的「綠色基準」評估，發表白皮書及發出通告，就銀行管理氣候風險提供指引及分享經驗。我們亦全力推進第二階段的工作，制定銀行業管理氣候風險的監管架構。此外，我們會致力在2025年或之前按照氣候相關財務披露工作小組的建議，要求銀行就氣候相關資料作出披露。這將使香港成為亞洲區內首個作出相關具體要求的地區。

金管局作為全球最大的儲備管理人之一，我們積極將環境、社會及管治(ESG)因素納入甄選、委任及監察外聘投資經理的程序。我們亦身體力行作出ESG投資，包括投資於綠色、社會及可持續債券和低碳項目。

為進一步發展香港的綠色金融生態圈，金管局一直協助政府發行綠色債券，而最近發行的第二批政府綠色債券更大受國際投資者歡迎。乘着這個發展趨勢，財政司司長在《2021至22年度財政預算案》中宣布政府會擴大「政府綠色債券計劃」的規模，將借款上限提升一倍至2,000億港元，並會增加日後發行的綠色債券的種類與發行渠道。

為鞏固香港作為區內綠色及可持續金融樞紐，我們整體策略的其中一環，是與本地其他監管機構及國際社會合作，推進綠色金融議程。在本地方面，金管局聯同其他監管機構成立綠色和可持續金融跨機構督導小組，協調金融業的相關措施。該小組已經制定策略性計劃，促進香港的綠色及可持續金融的發展。在國際方面，金管局應國際金融公司的邀請，成為亞洲區域創始成員及首個區域執行理事，與其合力推動「綠色商業銀行聯盟」。聯盟旨在於全球金融市場推動綠色銀行業，並由亞洲開始，逐步擴展至其他地區。

我們期望上述工作有助減低金融業面對的氣候風險，以及促進本港銀行發揮優勢，滿足區內綠色投資的龐大資金需求。

# 金融科技方便市民，裨益經濟

推動金融業增長的另一個主要引擎是金融科技，而在新冠病毒疫情下，這方面的步伐更見加速。

過去一年清楚顯示，金融科技能夠擴展我們的「工具箱」，以應對突如其來的衝擊。面對新冠病毒疫情，電子支付渠道發揮了前所未見的作用。自2018年9月推出快速支付系統「轉數快」至2020年底期間，「轉數快」已錄得690萬個登記賬戶。即使在社交距離措施的限制下，公眾仍能利用「轉數快」這個安全快捷及穩妥的方式收付及轉撥資金，令「轉數快」的平均每日交易量在2020年急增2.3倍。我們亦一直與政府合作，將「轉數快」的應用範圍擴大至繳付更多種政府及公共服務帳單。

此外，金融科技亦有助銀行提供更多元化及便利的銀行客戶服務。獲金管局發牌的所有8間虛擬銀行年內已經全數在香港開業。截至2020年底，在虛擬銀行開設的帳戶共有420,000個，總計客戶存款150億港元。其中部分虛擬銀行已經率先使用新類型數據進行信貸評估，以開拓新的客戶群及促進普及金融。金管局繼續推動在香港發展更具規模及更多元化的合規科技生態圈，作為「銀行易」措施的一部分，從而精簡監管規定，提升客戶體驗。除透過刊發通訊系列，以提高業界對合規科技應用的認知外，金管局亦發表白皮書，載述加快銀行業採用合規科技的兩年計劃。另外，金管局又展開「商業數據通」項目，以便中小企利用自身的數碼足跡更便捷地獲取銀行融資。

金融科技面貌日新月異，科技應用亦日趨普及，金管局需繼續秉持嚴謹的監管。為此，我們推出「網絡防衛計劃2.0」，以提高銀行的網絡防衛能力。我們亦加強對科技風險管理的現場審查，並制定監管框架，評估運用創新信用風險評估方法的個人貸款產品的信用風險。金管局亦展開監管科技應用的三年計劃，以提升監管流程的成效及前瞻性。我們現正進行的有關工作包括更有效地利用數據及科技來加強反洗錢方面的監管。

# Chairman's Report

2020 was a year that defied imagination.

The COVID-19 pandemic ravaged the globe, catching everyone off guard, and economic activity worldwide nearly came to a standstill. Under the impact of the pandemic, Hong Kong's economy contracted for the second consecutive year after 2019, recording its largest decline on record. The unemployment rate soared to a 16-year high, with some industries particularly hard hit.

However, adversity often presents an opportunity to demonstrate our strengths. Despite facing numerous challenges, Hong Kong’s monetary and banking system has once again successfully withstood the shocks. This was by no means accidental, but rather the result of our consistent adherence to prudent policies over the years.

The path to recovery is unlikely to be smooth. Even with full support from central banks and governments worldwide, the outlook remains fraught with uncertainty, including the stance of central bank monetary policy, the progress of vaccination programs, and the potential impact of a prolonged low-interest-rate environment. On the other hand, constantly evolving geopolitical tensions add further variables to the macroeconomic landscape.

Even facing such an uncertain situation, the Monetary Authority will continue to stand firm, maintain monetary and financial stability, and create an environment conducive to economic recovery. At the same time, in the constantly evolving banking and financial landscape, we will also strive to seize opportunities and enhance Hong Kong's competitiveness as a global financial hub.

# Monetary and Financial Stability: As Stable as Ever

The Linked Exchange Rate System (LERS) continued to operate smoothly and orderly in 2020. The LERS, which has been in place since 1983, has weathered numerous challenges over the years, fully demonstrating its resilience against shocks. Despite facing the pandemic and a volatile macroeconomic environment, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained stable throughout the year. The strong-side exchange guarantee was triggered a total of 85 times, with cumulative funds inflows of approximately 383.5 billion Hong Kong dollars.

The stability of the linked exchange rate system has been underpinned by the solid foundations built over the years. As noted in the summary by the International Monetary Fund in its External Sector Report 2020, the credibility of the linked exchange rate system is based on highly transparent operational rules, ample fiscal and foreign exchange reserves, robust financial regulation, a flexible economy, and prudent fiscal policies. At the same time, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) swiftly dispels rumors and timely provides the latest information on facts and data through close engagement with the industry and effective communication with the public via traditional and social media. The HKMA also continues to enhance its supervisory capabilities by leveraging the latest technology and data analytics to flexibly respond to the latest market conditions and emerging risks.

Although the epidemic has created significant pressure on the economy, the banking system remains stable, with ample capital and liquidity. As of the end of 2020, the capital adequacy ratio of local banks was 20.7%, far exceeding the international minimum requirement of 8%. The average liquidity coverage ratio of large banks was also far above the statutory minimum requirement of 100%, reaching 155.1% in the fourth quarter of 2020. Affected by the epidemic, the asset quality of banks deteriorated slightly, with the specific classified loan ratio rising to 0.9% at the end of 2020, but still remained stable and far below the long-term average level of 1.8% since 2000.

# banking sector: the lifeblood of the economy

The banking system plays a crucial role as a financial intermediary in the economy and society. Throughout the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) focused on closely regulating banks' credit and liquidity risks while also closely monitoring the impact of the pandemic on banking operations. The HKMA implemented multiple measures to ensure the banking system could continue providing essential services and offering loan support to the economy. In March, the HKMA reduced the countercyclical capital buffer ratio by 100 basis points to 1%, and in April, it lowered regulatory reserve levels. These measures collectively freed up approximately 100 billion Hong Kong dollars in lending capacity for the banking system.

We are fully aware that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) may face cash flow pressures under the current economic environment. Therefore, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), together with our SME loan coordination mechanism established in 2019, introduced multiple relief measures, including the "PPPHS" program, which deferred the principal repayments of all eligible enterprises for six months. By the end of 2020, banks had processed over 58,000 cases of loan deferrals and other support measures, involving over HK$740 billion. In response to the recurring pandemic, the HKMA extended the "PPPHS" program, prolonging it until the end of October 2021 in March 2021. Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation also launched the "Special 100% Loan Guarantee" under its SME financing guarantee program to alleviate SMEs' burdens in paying employee salaries and rent. By the end of 2020, over 25,000 applications had been approved, involving approximately HK$40 billion. The program was optimized in the first quarter of 2021, with the application deadline extended to December 31, 2021. Throughout the year, banks also processed over 28,000 relief measure applications for individual customers, assisting with cash flow needs involving HK$44 billion. The banking industry's united efforts in supporting both enterprises and individual customers through these challenging times are truly encouraging.

At the same time, the Monetary Authority continues to promote the banking sector to strengthen financial inclusion and practice a customer-centric culture. We further encourage banks to pay special attention to clients in need and share various good practices with them, including providing banking services for people with intellectual disabilities and offering more accessible and user-friendly banking services.

With the rapid development of technology, the operating environment of the banking industry has also changed rapidly. Therefore, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's work is not only about addressing current challenges but also looking ahead to expand the talent pool to meet the future needs of the banking industry. We have launched a research project, "Enhancing the Professional Competence of Future Banking Talent," in collaboration with the Hong Kong Bankers Association and the Hong Kong Institute of Bankers, to assess potential talent gaps in the banking industry over the next few years and provide banks with a clear roadmap to improve talent supply. We have also introduced the Banking Talent Programme, offering recent graduates from local universities a six-month internship and specialized training related to the banking industry, aiming to cultivate talent for the sector. Launching this program during a challenging period in the local labor market also provides opportunities for young people interested in joining the banking industry.

# Status as an International Financial Center: Fearless in the Face of Challenges

To fulfill one of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's key responsibilities—assisting in consolidating Hong Kong's status as an international financial center—our future plans encompass not only the banking system but also the entire financial system, aiming to ensure Hong Kong remains competitive in an ever-evolving financial environment. During the pandemic, we have steadily advanced these efforts and actively explored new opportunities in several key areas to fully capitalize on emerging trends and changes.

# Promote Green Finance and Create a More Sustainable Future

The first area of focus is promoting green and sustainable finance. Since the launch of measures to be implemented in three phases in May 2019, good progress has been made in related work. We completed the “Greenness Baseline” assessment of 47 banks in 2020, published a white paper, and issued a circular providing guidance and sharing experience on banks’ management of climate-related risks. We are also fully pushing forward the work of the second phase, formulating a regulatory framework for the banking sector’s management of climate-related risks. In addition, we will strive to require banks to make disclosures on climate-related data by 2025 or earlier, in accordance with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures. This will make Hong Kong the first region in Asia to make such specific requirements.

As one of the world’s largest reserve managers, we actively incorporate environmental, social and governance (ESG) factors into the selection, appointment and monitoring of external investment managers. We also practice ESG investing ourselves, including investments in green, social and sustainable bonds and low-carbon projects.

To further develop Hong Kong's green finance ecosystem, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been assisting the government in issuing green bonds, with the recent second batch of government green bonds receiving significant interest from international investors. Leveraging this development trend, the Financial Secretary announced in the 2021-22 Budget Address that the government would expand the "Government Green Bond Programme," doubling the borrowing limit to HKD 200 billion and increasing the variety of green bonds and issuance channels for future offerings.

To consolidate Hong Kong’s position as a regional hub for green and sustainable finance, one aspect of our overall strategy is to collaborate with other local regulators and the international community to advance the green finance agenda. Locally, the HKMA, together with other regulators, has established the Cross-agency Steering Group on Green and Sustainable Finance to coordinate relevant initiatives in the financial industry. The Group has formulated a strategic plan to promote the development of green and sustainable finance in Hong Kong. Internationally, the HKMA has accepted the invitation of the International Finance Corporation to become a founding member and the first regional executive council member for the Asia region, working with it to promote the Alliance for Green Commercial Banks. The Alliance aims to promote green banking in global financial markets, starting in Asia and gradually expanding to other regions.

We expect the aforementioned work to help reduce climate risks faced by the financial sector and encourage Hong Kong banks to leverage their strengths to meet the substantial funding needs for green investments in the region.

# FinTech brings convenience to citizens and benefits the economy.

Another major driver of growth in the financial sector is fintech, and the pace of development in this area has accelerated further during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The past year has clearly demonstrated that fintech can expand our "toolkit" to cope with unexpected shocks. In response to the coronavirus pandemic, electronic payment channels played an unprecedented role. From the launch of the Faster Payment System "FPS" in September 2018 until the end of 2020, FPS had already recorded 6.9 million registered accounts. Even under the restrictions of social distancing measures, the public could still use FPS - a secure, fast and reliable method - to make payments and transfer funds, leading to a 2.3-fold surge in FPS's average daily transaction volume in 2020. We have also continued to collaborate with the government to expand FPS's application scope to cover more types of government and public service bills.

In addition, fintech also helps banks provide more diversified and convenient banking services to customers. All eight virtual banks licensed by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) have already commenced operations in Hong Kong this year. As of the end of 2020, a total of 420,000 accounts had been opened with virtual banks, with total customer deposits amounting to HKD 15 billion. Some of these virtual banks have already started using new types of data for credit assessment, aiming to tap into new customer segments and promote financial inclusion. The HKMA continues to promote the development of a larger and more diversified compliance technology ecosystem in Hong Kong as part of the "Banking Easy" initiative, in order to streamline regulatory requirements and enhance customer experience. In addition to publishing a series of communications to raise industry awareness of compliance technology applications, the HKMA has also issued a white paper outlining a two-year plan to accelerate the adoption of compliance technology in the banking sector. Furthermore, the HKMA has launched the "Commercial Data Interchange" project to enable small and medium-sized enterprises to more conveniently access banking financing by leveraging their own digital footprints.

The landscape of financial technology is evolving rapidly, with technological applications becoming increasingly widespread. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) must continue to uphold rigorous regulation. To this end, we have launched the "Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative 2.0" to enhance banks' cyber defense capabilities. We have also strengthened on-site reviews of technology risk management and established a regulatory framework to assess the credit risk of personal loan products utilizing innovative credit risk assessment methods. The HKMA has also initiated a three-year plan to apply regulatory technology, aiming to improve the effectiveness and forward-looking nature of regulatory processes. Current efforts include more effectively leveraging data and technology to strengthen anti-money laundering regulations.

# 2020 年摘要

# 經濟及金融環境

面對新冠病毒疫情，香港經濟在2020年錄得有紀錄以來最大幅的收縮，消費及旅遊相關行業尤其受到重創。勞工市場急速惡化，通脹則有所緩和。政府及金管局為應對嚴峻的經濟環境，推出紓困措施支持經濟。

儘管面對重重挑戰，香港銀行體系保持穩健，財務狀況良好，存款繼續增長。資本及流動性維持充裕，資產質素仍處於穩健水平。

# 貨幣穩定

儘管疫情增加不確定因素，港元外匯及貨幣市場運作暢順有序，反映香港貨幣體系保持穩固。港元匯率於2020年大部分時間偏強，強方兌換保證多次被觸發。這充分展現聯繫匯率制度穩健，以及市場對制度的信心。

# 銀行體系穩定

金管局在密切留意疫情對銀行營運影響的同時，繼續重點監管銀行的信用及流動性風險管理。鑑於網絡風險持續增加以及業界加快採用科技，金管局加強對銀行科技風險管理及運作穩健性的監管，以及數碼金融服務消費者的保障。

金管局給予銀行彈性，以便銀行在疫情下能繼續為客戶提供服務。金管局又聯同其他有關當局制定「跨境理財通」業務試點的實施細則，以及就家族辦公室及財富管理業務提供指引。

在打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集方面，金管局迅速採取行動，不但釐清風險為本方法及科技如何協助銀行更有效應對與新冠病毒疫情相關的情況，並同時審慎管理持續升溫的地緣政治緊張局勢對銀行體系造成的影響。金管局亦繼續推動公私營夥伴共享訊息，以及支持銀行業採用合規科技。

年內推出多項加強銀行體系監管制度的新規則及規例，以符合最新的國際標準。在綠色及可持續銀行業方面，金管局已進入三個階段中的第二階段，正制定相關監管要求。金管局亦致力制定處置標準、進行處置規劃及建立處置執行能力，確保香港備有具公信力的銀行處置機制。

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

金管局繼續推動金融科技生態圈的發展，其中銀行及支付業界日益採用金融科技。快速支付系統「轉數快」交易量急增。金管局積極參與央行數碼貨幣等範疇的跨境合作。

香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位穩固，並繼續作為進入中國內地的主要門戶。香港與內地的金融聯繫繼續透過其世界級市場基建以及互聯互通機制而更趨緊密。年內在粵港澳大灣區發展方面亦取得良好進展。

金管局積極開拓新機遇，進一步提升香港金融平台，包括資產及財富管理企業財資中心，以及綠色與可持續金融範疇的競爭力。

# 儲備管理

儘管投資環境複雜多變，外匯基金在2020年錄得2,358億港元的投資收入，回報率為5.3%，而且5個主要投資類別均錄得正回報。

金管局繼續致力推動負責任投資及資產多元化。長期增長組合自2009年開展投資以來的內部回報率年率為13.7%。

# 機構職能及社會責任

年內金管局繼續透過不同渠道與社會及市場保持有效溝通，增進公眾對金管局政策及運作的了解。金管局在執行職務時，秉持極高的企業管治水平，支持員工提升專業能力、嚴格控制財政及加強資訊科技能力與保安，以應對新挑戰及項目，以及日益繁重的工作。

與此同時，金管局繼續致力履行機構社會責任，力求成為負責任及可持續發展的機構。在新冠病毒疫情下，金管局作出特別工作安排，確保重要職能繼續正常運作，並同時保障員工健康。金管局又推出多項措施，支援有需要的個人及企業，以減輕疫情造成的不利影響。

# 2020 Summary

# Economic and financial environment

Faced with the COVID-19 pandemic, Hong Kong's economy recorded its largest contraction on record in 2020, with consumer and tourism-related industries particularly hard hit. The labor market deteriorated rapidly, while inflation eased. To address the challenging economic environment, the government and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority introduced relief measures to support the economy.

Despite facing numerous challenges, the banking system in Hong Kong remains stable with sound financial conditions and continued deposit growth. Capital and liquidity remain ample, and asset quality remains at a healthy level.

# Monetary Stability

Despite the uncertainties introduced by the pandemic, the Hong Kong dollar's foreign exchange and monetary markets operated smoothly and orderly, reflecting the continued stability of Hong Kong's monetary system. The Hong Kong dollar's exchange rate remained strong for most of 2020, with the strong-side exchange guarantee being frequently triggered. This fully demonstrates the robustness of the linked exchange rate system and the market's confidence in it.

# Banking Stability

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to closely monitor the impact of the pandemic on banking operations while focusing on supervising banks’ credit and liquidity risk management. Given the ongoing increase in cyber risks and the industry’s accelerated adoption of technology, the HKMA has strengthened its oversight of banks’ technology risk management and operational resilience, as well as the protection of consumers of digital financial services.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has granted banks flexibility to continue providing services to customers during the pandemic. It has also worked with other relevant authorities to formulate the implementation details of the Wealth Management Connect pilot scheme, as well as to provide guidance on family offices and wealth management services.

In combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has swiftly taken action, not only clarifying how a risk-based approach and technology can help banks more effectively deal with situations related to the COVID-19 pandemic, but also carefully managing the impact of the escalating geopolitical tensions on the banking system. The HKMA continues to promote information sharing between the public and private sectors, as well as support the banking industry in adopting compliance technology.

New rules and regulations to strengthen the banking system’s regulatory framework will be introduced this year to align with the latest international standards. In the area of green and sustainable banking, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has entered the second phase of a three-phase plan and is currently developing relevant regulatory requirements. The HKMA is also committed to establishing resolution standards, conducting resolution planning, and building resolution execution capabilities to ensure Hong Kong has a credible bank resolution mechanism.

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

The HKMA continues to promote the development of the fintech ecosystem, with banks and the payment sector increasingly adopting fintech. The Faster Payment System has seen a rapid increase in transaction volume. The HKMA is actively participating in cross-border cooperation in areas such as central bank digital currency.

Hong Kong's position as a global offshore RMB business hub remains firmly established, and it continues to serve as the primary gateway to mainland China. Hong Kong's financial ties with the mainland continue to grow stronger through its world-class market infrastructure and interconnectivity mechanisms. Significant progress has also been made in the development of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area this year.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is actively exploring new opportunities to enhance Hong Kong's financial platform, including bolstering the competitiveness of corporate treasury centers supporting asset and wealth management, as well as in the areas of green and sustainable finance.

# Reserves Management

Despite a complex and volatile investment environment, the Foreign Exchange Fund recorded HK$235.8 billion in investment income in 2020, with a rate of return of 5.3%, and all five major investment categories recorded positive returns.

The Monetary Authority continues to strive for responsible investment and asset diversification. The long-term growth portfolio has achieved an annualized internal rate of return of 13.7% since the commencement of investments in 2009.

# Organizational functions and social responsibility.

Throughout the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continued to maintain effective communication with the public and the market through various channels, enhancing public understanding of the HKMA’s policies and operations. In carrying out its duties, the HKMA upheld a high level of corporate governance, supporting staff in enhancing their professional capabilities, strictly controlling finances, and strengthening information technology capabilities and security to meet new challenges and projects, as well as the increasingly heavy workload.

At the same time, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) remains committed to fulfilling its institutional social responsibility and becoming a responsible and sustainable institution. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the HKMA implemented special work arrangements to ensure the continued normal operation of essential functions while safeguarding the health of its employees. The HKMA also introduced various measures to support individuals and businesses in need, mitigating the adverse effects of the pandemic.

# 4月9日

金管局宣布透過減發200億港元外匯基金票據，增加銀行同業市場整體港元流動性，並在新冠病毒疫情對環球宏觀環境帶來波動的情況下，有助確保港元銀行同業市場維持暢順運作。

金管局宣布設立臨時性美元流動資金安排，為持牌銀行提供美元流動性支援及協助紓緩環球美元銀行拆借市場出現的流動性緊絀情況。

# 10月23日

金管局宣布指定9間認可機構作為香港離岸人民幣市場的一級流動性提供行。

中國人民銀行（人民銀行）與金管局公布已續簽為期5年的貨幣互換協議。協議規模由原來的4,000億元人民幣（4,700億港元）擴大至5,000億元人民幣（5,900億港元）。

# 3月16日

金管局公布，香港適用的逆周期緩衝資本比率由2.0%下調至1.0%，即時生效。

# 3月26日

金管局聯同社會福利署及香港銀行公會（銀行公會）推出措施，方便身處內地的社會保障受助人在疫情下無須親自返港，透過遙距渠道收取有關援助金或津貼。

# 4月17日

金管局聯同銀行業中小企貸款協調機制宣布推出「預先批核還息不還本」計劃，支援中小型企業（中小企）客戶。

# 4月20日

香港按證保險有限公司（按證保險公司）於「中小企融資擔保計劃」下推出的「百分百擔保特惠貸款」開始接受申請。

# 4月24日

《2020年銀行業（資本）（修訂）規則》刊憲。

金管局因應疫情設立專責查詢服務，協助「預先批核還息不還本」計劃客戶

# 5月7日

香港按揭證券有限公司（按揭證券公司）推出的「定息按揭試驗計劃」開始接受申請。

# 5月8日

金管局發出實施強制性背景查核計劃的諮詢文件，以減低認可機構聘用曾有失當行為紀錄人士的風險。

# 5月22日

金管局發表全面的《銀行文化自我評估的檢視報告》，為業界提供一系列做法以作參考。

# 5月29日

按證保險公司宣布「中小企融資擔保計劃」下「八成及九成信貸擔保產品」的優化措施，即時生效。

# 6月4日

金管局宣布聯同銀行業推出「銀行業人才起動計劃」，在疫情期間為應屆大學畢業生提供短期的工作機會及專業培訓。

# 6月30日

金管局公布綠色及可持續銀行業白皮書，闡述就應對氣候相關事項的監管方針的初步構思。

# 7月10日

金管局就加強監管信託業務的建議諮詢業界。

# 7月31日

金管局就銷售政府及相關組織發行的合資格零售債券的簡化安排向銀行提供指引。

# 8月5日

金管局聯同銀行業中小企貸款協調機制宣布延長「預先批核還息不還本計劃下貿易融資貸款還款期90天。

金管局與保監局合作，就使用視像會議銷售長期保險產品的監管要求向業界提供指引。

# 8月20日

金管局放寬非住宅物業按揭貸款的逆周期宏觀審慎監管措施，這類貸款的適用按揭成數上限上調，一般個案的上限由四成上調至五成。

# 9月30日

金管局就零售銀行銷售投資及保險產品的喬裝客戶檢查計劃，與業界分享主要觀察結果及良好手法。

按揭證券公司宣布「定息按揭試驗計劃」申請期將延長一年至2021年10月30日。

金管局制定促進本地銀行業採用合規科技兩年計劃，該計劃載於題為《善用合規科技力量：轉變風險管理及合規》白皮書內。

金管局宣布推出「網絡防衛計劃2.0」，以反映科技發展的最新趨勢，並融入全球網絡風險管理的最新做法，從而提升銀行業網絡防衛能力至更高水平。

在金管局的支持下，銀行公會與存款公司公會聯合發出《智障人士銀行服務指引》，列載建議的原則和良好做法，為有需要的客戶提供銀行服務。

# 12月18日

金管局宣布推出銀行專業資歷架構「業務操作風險管理」單元，以推動銀行業人才培訓及提升從業員的專業能力。

# Chronological Summary of Major Events in 2020

# Monetary Stability

# April 9th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced that it will increase overall Hong Kong dollar liquidity in the interbank market by issuing a reduced amount of Exchange Fund Notes totaling HK$20 billion, and help ensure the smooth functioning of the Hong Kong dollar interbank market amid volatility in the global macroeconomic environment due to the coronavirus pandemic.

# April 22

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced the establishment of a temporary US dollar liquidity arrangement to provide US dollar liquidity support to licensed banks and help alleviate the liquidity shortage in the global US dollar interbank lending market.

# October 23

The HKMA announced the designation of nine authorized institutions as primary liquidity providers for the offshore RMB market in Hong Kong.

# November 25

People’s Bank of China and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority have announced the extension of a currency swap agreement for a period of five years. The agreement size has been expanded from the original 400 billion yuan (4,700 billion Hong Kong dollars) to 500 billion yuan (5,900 billion Hong Kong dollars).

# Banking sector

# February 21

The Financial Services and Treasury Bureau and the Insurance Authority (IA) introduced temporary facilitative measures in response to the pandemic, allowing non-face-to-face sales of specific insurance products, and cooperated to review sandbox schemes involving authorized institutions selling insurance products through non-face-to-face methods.

# March 16th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced that the countercyclical capital buffer ratio applicable in Hong Kong has been lowered from 2.0% to 1.0%, effective immediately.

# March 26

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the Social Welfare Department and the Hong Kong Association of Banks (HKAB), has introduced measures to facilitate social security beneficiaries in mainland China to receive the relevant assistance or subsidies through remote channels without having to return to Hong Kong in person during the pandemic.

# April 17

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), together with the SME Loan Coordination Mechanism in the banking sector, announced the launch of the “Pre-Approval Repayment of Interest but Not Principal” (PPPHS) scheme to support SMEs customers.

# April 20th

HKMC Insurance Limited (HKMCI) has started accepting applications for the "Special 100% Loan Guarantee" under the "SME Financing Guarantee Scheme".

# April 24th

Banking (Capital) (Amendment) Rules 2020 have been published.

The HKMA has set up a dedicated inquiry service in response to the pandemic to assist "PPPHS" plan customers

# May 7th

The Fixed-rate Mortgage Pilot Scheme launched by Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation Limited (HKMC) has started accepting applications.

# May 8th

The HKMA issued a consultation document on implementing a mandatory background check program to reduce the risk of licensed institutions hiring individuals with a record of misconduct.

# May 22

The HKMA has issued a comprehensive Report on Review of Self-assessments on Bank Culture, providing the industry with a series of practices for reference.

# May 29th

According to the announcement by the insurance company regarding the optimization measures for the “80% and 90% loan guarantee products” under the SME Financing Guarantee Scheme, the measures take effect immediately.

# June 4th

The Financial Supervisory Commission announced, in conjunction with the banking sector, the launch of the Banking Talent Programme, providing short-term employment opportunities and professional training for recent university graduates during the pandemic.

# June 30

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) published a Green and Sustainable Banking White Paper, outlining initial proposals for regulatory frameworks to address climate-related issues.

# July 10th

The Monetary Authority consulted the industry on recommendations to strengthen the regulation of trust business.

# July 31st

The Monetary Authority has provided guidance to banks regarding the simplified arrangements for the sale of eligible retail bonds issued by the government and related organizations.

# August 5th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, in conjunction with the Coordination Mechanism for SME Loan Facilitation in the Banking Sector, announced the extension of the repayment period for trade financing loans under the Pre-Approved Interest-Only Repayment Plan by 90 days.

The Monetary Authority and the Insurance Supervision Bureau collaborate to provide guidance to the industry on regulatory requirements for selling long-term insurance products via video conferencing.

# August 20

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has relaxed the countercyclical macroprudential measures for mortgage loans on non-residential properties, raising the applicable loan-to-value ratio limit for such loans from 40% to 50% for general cases.

# September 2

To alleviate the financial pressure on SMEs, Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation announced that the application period for the principal repayment deferral measures under the “80% and 90% Credit Guarantee Products” of the ‘SME Financing Guarantee Scheme’ will be extended by 6 months to March 31, 2021.

On the same day, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced in conjunction with the SME Loan Coordination Mechanism of the Banking Sector the extension of the PPPHS program for six months until April 30, 2021.

# September 4

The Monetary Authority issued a notice requiring banks to implement enhanced disclosure measures, providing "double warnings" to retail individual customers and small and medium-sized enterprise customers applying for unsecured loans and credit card products through digital platforms.

# September 18

Under the SME Financing Guarantee Scheme, the maximum loan amount for each enterprise under the Special 100% Loan Guarantee has been increased to the total of 12 months’ employee salaries and rent, or HK$5 million, whichever is lower; the maximum repayment period has been extended to 5 years.

# September 29th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) published the report "AML/CFT Supervision in the Age of Digital Innovation," outlining how it will strengthen the application of data and regulatory technology in risk-based anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing supervision as part of the HKMA's digital transformation initiative.

# September 30th

The HKMA shared key observations and good practices from its undercover customer checks on the sale of investment and insurance products by retail banks with the industry.

# November 2

The mortgage-backed securities company announced that the application period for the Fixed-rate Mortgage Pilot Scheme will be extended for one year to October 30, 2021.

# November 3rd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has launched a two-year initiative to encourage the local banking sector to adopt RegTech, as outlined in the white paper titled "Leveraging the Power of RegTech: Transforming Risk Management and Compliance."

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced the launch of Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative 2.0, reflecting the latest trends in technological development and incorporating the newest practices in global cyber risk management, thereby elevating the cybersecurity capabilities of the banking sector to a higher level.

# December 15th

With the support of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Banking Guild and the Depositors' Guild jointly issued the 'Guideline on Banking Services for Persons with Intellectual Disabilities', which lists suggested principles and good practices to provide banking services to clients in need.

# December 18

The Monetary Authority has announced the launch of the "Operational Risk Management" unit within the Banking Professional Qualification Framework to promote talent training and enhance the professional capabilities of employees in the banking sector.

# December 23

The HKMA provides guidance to banks on offering investment services through non-face-to-face channels and on simplifying product disclosure for non-retail bank customers who are familiar with investments.

# December 31

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) published a summary of its public consultation on the proposed subsidiary legislation under section 92 of the Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance (Cap. 628) to establish rules suspending the termination rights of financial contracts applicable to authorized institutions, and consulted the industry on the draft rules.

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

# January 22nd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Bank of Thailand announced the results of the joint research project on central bank digital currencies – the “Inthanon-LionRock” project – and published a research report. The project aims to study the application of central bank digital currencies in cross-border payments.

# February

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority was appointed as Joint Chairman of the Evaluation and Compliance Group under the Financial Action Task Force for a two-year term from 2020 to 2022. The Financial Action Task Force is an organization that sets global standards to combat money laundering, headquartered in Paris, France.

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

# May 5th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Securities and Futures Commission jointly initiated the Inter-Agency Steering Group on Green and Sustainable Finance.

# May 20th

The Hong Kong Monetary and Financial Research Centre released its first applied finance research report, titled "Fintech Adoption and Innovation in the Hong Kong Banking Industry."

# June 29th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the People's Bank of China and the Macao Financial Services Bureau, issued a joint announcement, announcing the launch of the "Wealth Management Connect" business pilot in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area.

# August 3rd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Hong Kong Centre under the BIS Innovation Hub have launched the TechChallenge Digitising Trade Finance initiative.

# August 19

The Governor of the Monetary Authority presided over the first session of the 25th Governors' Meeting of the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks (EMEAP) via video conference. The second session of the meeting was held via video conference on November 16.

# August 21

The Hong Kong Institute for Monetary and Financial Research published its second Applied Financial Research Report titled "Artificial Intelligence in Banking: The Changing Landscape in Compliance and Supervision."

# August 31

The implementation of the Limited Partnerships Fund Ordinance (Chapter 637) allows investment funds to be established in Hong Kong under a limited liability partnership structure.

# November 2nd to 6th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Investment Promotion Agency co-hosted the Hong Kong FinTech Week 2020, attracting over 1.2 million viewers from more than 130 economies. They announced a series of initiatives, including CDI and linking eTradeConnect with the People’s Bank of China’s Trade Finance Platform, to build a supportive ecosystem for fintech, supporting various businesses, especially SMEs.

# November 3rd

The 4th "Hong Kong and Swiss Financial Cooperation Dialogue" was jointly hosted by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Directorate for International Financial Matters of the Swiss Federal Department of Finance in an online format.

# November 9th

The Financial Supervisory Commission signed a new cooperation agreement with the International Finance Corporation, a member of the World Bank Group, to promote the Alliance for Green Commercial Banks, encouraging commercial banks in Asia to develop strategies and goals for a greener future.

# November 16

The seventh batch of retail inflation-linked bonds (iBond) has been issued under the government bond program.

# November 24th

The Centre for Monetary and Financial Studies in Hong Kong has published its third Applied Finance Research Report, titled "The Green Bond Market in Hong Kong: Developing a Robust Ecosystem for Sustainable Growth."

# November 27

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced its appointment as Chairman of the Task Force on Enforcement Actions under EMEAP; this task force is a dedicated mechanism organization that provides support for knowledge sharing and discussions among relevant authorities in the region regarding cross-border enforcement actions.

# December 6th

The Faster Payment System has introduced a new feature allowing citizens to link their bank accounts using their Hong Kong identity card numbers through their banks to receive payments issued by institutions.

# December 14th to 15th

The Green Finance Centre established by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office and the IFC jointly held the inaugural IFC Climate Business Webinar.

# December 17

The Inter-Agency Oversight Group on Green and Sustainable Finance released a strategic plan for green and sustainable finance, proposing to strengthen Hong Kong's financial ecosystem from six aspects.

# December 21

The TransferFast payment feature has been expanded to government fee payment counters and self-service kiosks.

# December 22

The fifth batch of silver bonds is issued under the government bond program.

# December 17, 21, and 22

The Monetary Authority led a delegation of banking industry representatives to hold an annual meeting with financial regulatory authorities in the mainland via video conference, discussing the current status of financial development in both regions.

# Reserves Management

# December 18

The Monetary Authority announced that it will conduct a market survey regarding the "Hong Kong Growth Portfolio," which serves as a part of the government's "Future Fund."

# Corporate Functions

# November 13

The Monetary Authority of Hong Kong launched a public education web series titled "STEPS" on its social media platforms, introducing the various work areas of the Monetary Authority.

# December 31

In 2020, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority opened up an additional 11 sets of financial data published on its website through open application programming interfaces (APIs) for the public to use free of charge.

# 經濟及金融環境

面對新冠病毒疫情，香港經濟在2020 年連續第二年收縮，並錄得歷年來最嚴重的跌幅。消費及旅遊相關行業尤其受到重創，其收縮幅度較整體經濟更大。與此同時，勞工市場急速惡化，通脹有所緩和。政府及金管局為應對嚴峻的經濟環境，推出歷來最大規模的紓困措施以支持經濟。新冠病毒疫苗接種可望使經濟活動回復正常，預期2021年經濟會恢復增長，然而經濟復甦的力度及步伐仍受疫情發展以及疫苗供應、覆蓋範圍和成效等眾多不明朗因素影響。

# 經濟回顧

# 實體經濟活動

受新冠病毒疫情打擊，香港經濟在2020年收縮6.1%，是連續第二年收縮，亦是有紀錄以來最嚴重的年度跌幅（表1）。經濟活動急跌主要是本地需求急劇收縮所致（圖1）。疫情爆發及相應的社交距離措施令本地消費活動受到重創。由於營商環境轉差，整體投資支出亦明顯減少。對外方面，儘管疫情導致供應鏈受干擾及全球需求萎縮，但部分受惠於中國內地迅速恢復生產和經濟活動，全年合計香港貨物出口僅略為下降。相比之下，由於封城、關閉邊境及旅客流量限制令全球旅遊業陷入停頓，所以香港服務輸出嚴重受挫。本地及轉口帶動的需求疲弱，亦令貨物進口及服務輸入轉差。由於進口總額下跌步伐較出口快，淨出口（貿易順差）為本地生產總值帶來支持（圖1）。按經濟行業分析，消費及旅遊相關行業，例如零售、住宿及膳食服務業受到的打擊尤其嚴重，收縮情況較整體經濟更差，而金融業則溫和增長。

表 1 按開支項目計的實質本地生產總值增長（比對上期）

# 經濟及金融環境

圖 1 組成部分對實質本地生產總值增長的貢獻

政府為應對疫情，透過2020至21年度《財政預算案》迅速推出歷來最大規模的紓困措施，並從「防疫抗疫基金」發放4輪補助，合共超過3,000億港元。這些措施包括向合資格居民發放一筆過10,000港元現金、透過「保就業」計劃提供工資補貼，以及為受疫情重創的行業提供一筆過資助、寬減租金及豁免收費。金管局則採取三管齊下的方式支持銀行業，從而支撐實體經濟。有關措施包括與銀行業積極協調，減輕企業及家庭的資金周轉壓力，釋放緩衝以提高銀行的借貸能力，並確保銀行有足夠流動性支持本地經濟活動。

# 通脹

通脹壓力在2020年明顯減弱。剔除政府一次性紓困措施的影響，基本通脹率放緩至1.3%，是2009年全球金融危機以來最小的升幅。基本食品（尤其新鮮豬肉）的價格壓力明顯減退；而自行烹煮以外，由於飲食業提供大幅度折扣，所以外出用膳的價格在下半年亦有所下降。隨着早前新簽訂的私人住宅租金回落，消費物價指數租金項目的增長亦回軟（圖2）。更廣泛而言，由於名義工資增長減慢及商業樓宇租金偏軟，本地營商成本壓力減少；而在疲弱的全球經濟狀況下，進口價格通脹有所緩和。

圖 2 基本消費物價通脹

# 勞工市場

勞工市場在2020年急速惡化。經季節性調整的失業率年內由3.3%飆升至6.6%，為16年的高位（圖3），其中零售、住宿及膳食服務等受疫情重創行業的失業率達到10%以上。就業不足率亦於8月升至3.8%，為沙士疫情後的高位。部分由於經濟狀況急速惡化造成的周期性反應，勞動人口參與率輕微減少。總就業人數（圖3）及私營機構職位空缺急跌，反映整體勞工需求進一步收縮。名義工資及收入增長進一步放緩。政府推出「保就業」計劃，為僱主提供有時限的財政支援以保留僱員，使勞工市場獲得一定程度的支持。

圖 3 勞工市場狀況

# 股市

隨着新冠病毒疫情爆發，恒生指數在首季急跌至3年低位。繼各國中央銀行及政府推出大型支持措施後，股市在第2季及第3季略為回穩（圖4）。由於新冠病毒疫苗研發出現突破，股市於接近年底時重拾一些上升動力。恒生指數於年底收報27,231點，全年計錄得3.4%跌幅。受惠於內地企業在香港的第二上市活動，2020年本港首次公開招股集資總額約4,000億港元，以集資額計全球排名第二。

圖 4 資產價格

# 物業市場

部分受到超低利率所支持，住宅物業市場在2020年大致平穩（圖4）。整體樓價及成交量較前一年均無大變動。然而，由於家庭住戶入息減少，置業負擔能力更為偏緊。另一方面，非住宅物業市場進一步轉弱，物業價格錄得不同程度跌幅，成交量亦見底。受經濟下滑及空置率上升的影響，寫字樓及零售物業租金大幅下跌。鑑於2019年以來非住宅物業市場已出現大幅調整，並預期會持續受壓，加上考慮到經濟基調及外圍環境等其他因素，金管局於8月調整非住宅物業的逆周期宏觀審慎監管措施。政府因應市場需求回落，亦於11月撤銷購置非住宅物業的雙倍從價印花稅這項需求管理措施。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

新冠病毒疫苗接種可望使經濟活動回復正常，預期香港經濟在2021年（全年合計）重拾正增長，然而經濟復甦的力度及步伐仍受疫情發展及疫苗供應、覆蓋範圍和成效等眾多不明朗因素影響。具體而言，疫苗廣泛接種需時，因此本地經濟在2021年早段仍面對相當程度的挑戰。對外方面，預計內地經濟會進一步增強，並為香港貨物及服務輸出帶來支持，然而其他主要經濟體的復甦步伐將取決於其大規模接種疫苗計劃的成效。政府預測2021年實質本地生產總值增長率介乎3.5至5.5%之間，與國際組織及私營機構分析員對香港最新的增長預測平均4.4%相符。

# 通脹及勞工市場

鑑於環球及本地經濟狀況仍具挑戰，預期2021年的通脹壓力將維持輕微。此外，早前新簽訂私人住宅租金回落的傳遞效應，將繼續令本地通脹受到抑制。市場共識預測2021年整體通脹率為1.5%，而政府預期整體及基本通脹率分別為1.6%及1%。由於經濟前景在2021年早段仍具挑戰，加上私營機構分析員預計2021年全年失業率仍會在約5.9%的偏高水平，因此短期內勞工市場將繼續受壓。

# 銀行體系表現

香港銀行體系在2020年保持穩健，銀行財務狀況良好。儘管新冠病毒疫情帶來挑戰，銀行資產負債表繼續擴大，存款資金增加。銀行體系資本及流動性狀況維持充裕，資產質素輕微轉差，但仍處穩健水平。

# 資產負債表走勢

2020年銀行體系資產負債表擴大5.7%。由於經濟下滑，年內貸款增長減慢至1.2%，相比2019年的增幅為6.7%；其中在香港使用的貸款增加2.2%，在香港境外使用的貸款微增0.1%，貿易融資減少6.2%。2020年中國內地相關貸款微跌0.2%，相比2019年錄得7.4%的增長。

銀行資產負債表的負債方面，存款總額在2020年增加5.4%，相比2019年的增幅為2.9%。由於存款總額增長較貸款總額快，整體貸存比率由2019年底的75.3% 降至 2020 年底的 72.3%（圖 5）。

圖 5 銀行體系的貸款及存款

# 資本充足水平

2020年銀行體系資本狀況維持穩健，為抵禦潛在衝擊提供強大的緩衝。2020年底本地註冊認可機構的綜合總資本比率與2019年底相比維持穩定，為20.7%。一級資本比率於同期由18.5%微升至18.7%（圖 6）。

2020年底《巴塞爾協定三》槓桿比率與2019年底相比維持穩定，仍為8.2%，遠高於3%的法定最低要求（圖 7）。

銀行體系的資金來源維持穩定。於2020年底，第1類機構的穩定資金淨額比率為138.6%，遠高於100%的法定最低要求。第2A類機構的核心資金比率為139.5%，亦遠高於75%的法定最低要求（圖 9）。

新冠病毒疫情影響下，年內銀行體系資產質素略為下降，但以歷史及國際標準計仍然維持良好。特定分類貸款比率由2019年底的0.57%上升至2020年底的0.90%，逾期及經重組貸款比率於同期由0.34%上升至0.57%（圖10）。中國內地相關貸款的特定分類貸款比率由 2019 年底的 0.75% 上升至 2020 年底的 0.96%。住宅按揭貸款及信用卡貸款的拖欠比率仍然處於低位，分別為0.04%及0.27%（圖11）。

# Economic and financial environment

Facing the COVID-19 pandemic, Hong Kong's economy contracted for the second consecutive year in 2020, recording its worst-ever decline. Consumer and tourism-related industries were particularly hard hit, contracting more sharply than the overall economy. Meanwhile, the labor market deteriorated rapidly, while inflation eased. To address the challenging economic environment, the government and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the largest-ever relief measures to support the economy. The rollout of COVID-19 vaccines is expected to restore normal economic activity, with economic growth anticipated to rebound in 2021. However, the strength and pace of the economic recovery remain subject to numerous uncertainties, including the evolution of the pandemic, vaccine supply, coverage, and effectiveness.

# Economic Review

# Real Economic Activities

Hit by the coronavirus pandemic, Hong Kong's economy contracted by 6.1% in 2020, marking the second consecutive year of contraction and the worst annual decline on record (Table 1). The sharp drop in economic activity was mainly due to a sudden contraction in local demand (Figure 1). The outbreak of the virus and the corresponding social distancing measures severely impacted local consumption. Due to the deteriorating business environment, overall investment spending also significantly decreased. Externally, although the pandemic disrupted supply chains and caused a global decline in demand, some benefits were derived from the rapid recovery of production and economic activities in mainland China, resulting in only a slight decline in Hong Kong's total goods exports for the year. In contrast, Hong Kong's service exports were severely affected due to the lockdowns, border closures, and travel restrictions that brought global tourism to a standstill. Weak demand driven by local and re-export activities also led to a decline in goods imports and service inputs. As the decline in imports was faster than that of exports, net exports (trade surplus) provided support to the local gross domestic product (Figure 1). By industry analysis, consumption and tourism-related sectors, such as retail, accommodation, and food services, were particularly hard hit, experiencing a contraction worse than that of the overall economy, while the financial sector showed moderate growth.

Table 1: Real Local GDP Growth by Expenditure Category (Compared to the Previous Period)

# Economic and financial environment

Figure 1 shows the contribution of various components to real local gross domestic product growth.

The government, to address the epidemic, swiftly launched the largest-ever relief measures through the 2020-21 Budget, and disbursed four rounds of subsidies from the Anti-Epidemic Fund, totaling over HK$3,000 billion. These measures included a one-off cash payment of HK$10,000 to eligible residents, providing wage subsidies through the "Employment Retention Scheme," and providing one-off grants, rent reductions, and fee waivers for industries severely affected by the epidemic. The Monetary Authority adopted a three-pronged approach to support the banking sector, thereby supporting the real economy. These measures included actively coordinating with the banking sector to alleviate the financial turnover pressure of businesses and families, releasing buffers to enhance banks' lending capacity, and ensuring that banks have sufficient liquidity to support local economic activities.

# Inflation

Inflationary pressures eased noticeably in 2020. Excluding the effect of the government’s one-off relief measures, the underlying inflation rate slowed to 1.3%, the smallest increase since the global financial crisis in 2009. Price pressures on basic food items (particularly fresh pork) diminished significantly; and the prices of dining out also fell in the second half of the year, as the catering industry offered substantial discounts in addition to cooking at home. With the recent signing of new private residential rental agreements leading to a fall in rents, the growth in the rental component of the Consumer Price Index also softened (Figure 2). More broadly, local business operating costs decreased due to slower nominal wage growth and softer commercial building rents; and import price inflation eased against the backdrop of a weak global economic environment.

Figure 2: Core Consumer Price Inflation

# Labour Market

The labor market deteriorated rapidly in 2020. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose from 3.3% to 6.6% within the year, reaching a 16-year high (Figure 3), with unemployment rates in sectors severely impacted by the pandemic, such as retail, accommodation, and food and beverage services, exceeding 10%. The underemployment rate also climbed to 3.8% in August, the highest since the SARS outbreak. Partly due to the cyclical response caused by the rapid deterioration of the economic situation, the labor force participation rate slightly declined. Total employment numbers (Figure 3) and private sector job vacancies plummeted, reflecting a contraction in overall labor demand. Nominal wage and income growth continued to slow. The government introduced the "Job Retention" plan, providing employers with time-limited financial support to retain employees, offering some support to the labor market.

Figure 3: Labor Market Conditions

# Stock Market

Following the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Hang Seng Index plummeted to a three-year low in the first quarter. After central banks and governments around the world launched large-scale support measures, the stock market stabilized slightly in the second and third quarters (Figure 4). Driven by breakthroughs in the development of COVID-19 vaccines, the stock market regained some upward momentum towards the end of the year. The Hang Seng Index closed at 27,231 points at the end of the year, recording an overall decrease of 3.4% for the year. Benefiting from the secondary listing activities of mainland Chinese companies in Hong Kong, Hong Kong’s total IPO fundraising in 2020 was approximately HK$400 billion, ranking second globally in terms of funds raised.

Figure 4 Asset Price

# Real Estate Market

Partly supported by ultra-low interest rates, the residential property market remained largely stable in 2020 (Figure 4). Overall property prices and transaction volumes showed little change compared to the previous year. However, due to a decline in household incomes, affordability for home purchases became tighter. On the other hand, the non-residential property market further weakened, with property prices declining to varying degrees and transaction volumes hitting a trough. Affected by economic contraction and rising vacancy rates, office and retail property rents fell sharply. Given that the non-residential property market had already experienced significant adjustments since 2019 and was expected to continue facing pressure, and considering other factors such as the economic outlook and external environment, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority adjusted the countercyclical macroprudential measures for non-residential properties in August. In response to the decline in market demand, the government also revoked the double-rate stamp duty on non-residential property purchases, a demand management measure, in November.

# Economic Prospects

# Economic Environment

Vaccination against the novel coronavirus is expected to restore normal economic activities, and Hong Kong's economy is anticipated to resume positive growth for the full year of 2021. However, the pace and strength of the economic recovery remain subject to numerous uncertainties, including the development of the pandemic, vaccine supply, coverage, and effectiveness. Specifically, since widespread vaccination will take time, the local economy will still face significant challenges in the early part of 2021. Externally, it is expected that the mainland economy will continue to strengthen and provide support for Hong Kong's exports of goods and services. However, the recovery pace of other major economies will depend on the effectiveness of their large-scale vaccination programs. The government forecasts that the real GDP growth rate of Hong Kong in 2021 will be between 3.5 and 5.5 percent, consistent with the average growth forecast of 4.4 percent by international organizations and private sector analysts.

# Inflation and the Labor Market

Given the ongoing challenges in global and local economic conditions, inflationary pressures in 2021 are expected to remain mild. Furthermore, the pass-through effect of the recent decline in private residential rents will continue to suppress local inflation. Market consensus forecasts an overall inflation rate of 1.5% for 2021, while the government expects overall and core inflation rates to be 1.6% and 1%, respectively. Due to the continued challenges in the economic outlook during the early part of 2021, combined with private sector analysts' expectations that the unemployment rate will remain at a relatively high level of around 5.9% for the entire year of 2021, the labor market is expected to remain under pressure in the short term.

# Banking system performance

The Hong Kong banking system remained stable in 2020, with banks in sound financial condition. Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, bank balance sheets continued to expand, and deposit funding increased. The banking system maintained ample capital and liquidity, while asset quality declined slightly but remained at a stable level.

# Balance sheet trends

In 2020, the banking system’s balance sheet expanded by 5.7%. Due to the economic downturn, loan growth slowed to 1.2% during the year, compared to an increase of 6.7% in 2019; among these, loans used in Hong Kong increased by 2.2%, while loans used outside of Hong Kong saw a slight increase of 0.1%, and trade financing decreased by 6.2%. In 2020, loans related to mainland China saw a slight decrease of 0.2%, compared to a 7.4% increase in 2019.

On the liabilities side of the bank's balance sheet, total deposits increased by 5.4% in 2020, compared to an increase of 2.9% in 2019. Since the growth in total deposits outpaced that of total loans, the overall loan-to-deposit ratio decreased from 75.3% at the end of 2019 to 72.3% at the end of 2020 (Figure 5).

Figure 5: Loans and Deposits in the Banking System

# Capital adequacy

The banking sector’s capital position remained robust in 2020, providing a strong buffer against potential shocks. The consolidated total capital ratio of locally registered institutions remained stable compared to the end of 2019, at 20.7%. The Tier 1 capital ratio rose slightly from 18.5% to 18.7% during the same period (Figure 6).

At the end of 2020, the Basel III leverage ratio remained stable compared to the end of 2019, at 8.2%, well above the statutory minimum requirement of 3% (Figure 7).

Figure 6 Comprehensive Capital Ratio of Locally Registered Accredited Institutions

Figure 7 Comprehensive Leverage Ratio of Locally Registered Accredited Institutions

# Liquidity Status

The banking system’s liquidity position remains stable and is capable of withstanding liquidity shocks. The average liquidity coverage ratio for Tier 1 institutions was 155.1% in the fourth quarter, significantly exceeding the statutory minimum requirement of 100%. The average liquidity maintenance ratio for Tier 2 institutions was 57.9%, also significantly above the statutory minimum requirement of 25% (Figure 8).

Figure 8: Liquidity Ratios of Designated Accredited Institutions

The banking system's funding sources remain stable. At the end of 2020, the net stable funding ratio for Category 1 institutions was 138.6%, far exceeding the statutory minimum requirement of 100%. The core capital ratio for Category 2A institutions was 139.5%, also significantly surpassing the statutory minimum requirement of 75% (Figure 9).

Figure 9: Funding Ratios of Designated Accredited Institutions

# Asset Quality

Under the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the asset quality of the banking system declined slightly during the year, but remained sound by historical and international standards. The specific classification loan ratio increased from 0.57% at the end of 2019 to 0.90% at the end of 2020, while the overdue and restructured loan ratio rose from 0.34% to 0.57% during the same period (Figure 10). The specific classification loan ratio for loans related to Mainland China increased from 0.75% at the end of 2019 to 0.96% at the end of 2020. The delinquency ratios for residential mortgage loans and credit card loans remained at low levels, at 0.04% and 0.27% respectively (Figure 11).

Figure 10: Asset Quality of the Banking System

Figure 11: Mortgage Loan and Credit Card Loan Delinquency Ratios

# Profitability Trends

Low interest rates coupled with a slight decline in asset quality have put pressure on the banking system's profitability. The overall pre-tax operating profit of retail banks declined by 29.4% in 2020 (Figure 12), mainly due to a decrease in net interest income (-21.9%) and an increase in loan impairment provisions (+61.3%). The net interest margin narrowed from 1.63% in 2019 to 1.18% in 2020 (Figure 13).

Due to decreased revenue, the cost-to-income ratio of retail banks rose from 39.5% in 2019 to 46.8% in 2020 (Figure 14).

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：
- 負債證明書（為3間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣
- 設於金管局的結算戶口結餘總額（即總結餘）
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。當強方（或弱方）兌換保證被觸發，金管局會應銀行要求，按每美元兌7.75港元向銀行沽出港元、買入美元（或按7.85港元買入港元、沽出美元），使總結餘增加（或減少），令港元利率下跌（或上升），從而促使港元匯率回復到7.75至7.85 的兌換範圍。

# 2020年回顧

# 匯率穩定

隨着3月全球爆發新冠病毒疫情，避險情緒下環球投資者增持美元，令美元資金狀況明顯收緊。在聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）下，由於港元利率受同期美元利率影響，美元流動性緊張令香港貨幣狀況收緊。儘管其後美國聯邦儲備局實施流動資金計劃，美元資金壓力有所紓緩，但由於股票相關需求及季結效應，令香港貨幣狀況仍維持偏緊。而港元需求殷切，加上港元與美元的正息差刺激套息交易活動，促使港元匯率偏向強方兌換保證匯率（圖1），強方兌換保證最終於4月被觸發。其後新股集資活動暢旺，以及「滬港通」與「深港通」下的南向資金帶動股票相關資金流入，令港元一直維持接近7.75水平，並導致強方兌換保證在2020年內多次被觸發。強方兌換保證在4月21日至10月28日期間合共被觸發85次，累計資金流入3,835億港元。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2020年全年運作正常。

# 貨幣市場

隨着農曆新年假期後流動性需求減退，香港銀行同業拆息在2月普遍下降（圖3）。踏入3月，由於美元資金壓力，連同新股集資相關及季結資金需求等本地因素，香港銀行同業拆息一度上升。其後由於強方兌換保證被觸發及外匯基金票據發行量減少，令總結餘增加，港元流動性狀況逐步紓緩。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍於3月兩度下調，以及反映年內隔夜與1個月香港銀行同業拆息變動，基本利率由年初的2.73厘下降至年底收報0.50厘。在零售層面，儘管美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍調低，銀行仍維持最優惠貸款利率不變。整體而言，香港貨幣市場繼續正常運作。貼現窗借貸由2019年的383億港元降至2020年的91億港元。

# 聯繫匯率制度

過去30多年來，聯匯制度一直是香港金融體系的重要支柱，歷經考驗均能展現強大的抵禦衝擊的能力。儘管2020年面對挑戰，港元外匯及貨幣市場保持正常運作，一再證明聯匯制度穩健有效。年內面對一些毫無根據的謠言，質疑聯匯制度以至香港的金融穩定，金管局迅速向公眾重申香港會繼續實施聯匯制度，同時資金自由流動及港幣自由兌換受到《基本法》第112條保障。金管局另又發表多篇文章，闡明逆境下香港金融體系繼續展現強大抵禦衝擊能力的事實。政府亦堅決維持聯匯制度。香港的金融市場有序運作，以及港元繼續如常作為支付及保值貨幣，反映上述措施有效維持公眾對聯匯制度的信心。國際貨幣基金組織在《2020年對外部門報告》重申香港擁有具透明度的規則、充裕的財政及外匯儲備、穩健的金融規管與監管、靈活的經濟，以及審慎的財政架構，確保聯匯制度具公信力。

穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用。儘管新冠病毒疫情構成負面影響，香港銀行體系繼續運作暢順，流動性及資本水平以國際標準而言均非常充裕。為確保銀行體系具備承受衝擊的能力，金管局一直密切監察銀行的信用、流動性及利率風險管理，以及壓力測試結果，並維持對銀行貸款的監管。與此同時，金管局亦為銀行體系提供更多流動性，維持貨幣及金融穩定。除減發外匯基金票據以增加港元流動性外，金管局為銀行設立一系列流動資金安排。此外，金管局與銀行保持聯繫，確保它們在緊張情況時利用這些流動資金安排。因應新冠病毒疫情為環球金融市場帶來波動及不確定因素，金管局推出臨時性美元流動資金安排，為持牌銀行提供美元流動性支援，有助紓緩環球美元銀行拆借市場流動性緊絀的情況。

為提高貨幣發行局帳目的透明度，自1998年10月起，外匯基金已有部分資產被指定用作支持貨幣基礎。支持比率（即支持資產相對貨幣基礎的比率）於2020年在109.8至112.1%之間上落，並無觸及上限或下限。該比率於12月31日收報109.9%（圖4）。在聯匯制度下，雖然已指定某些外匯基金資產作為支持組合，但外匯基金的全部資產均可用作支持港元匯率。外匯基金的龐大財政資源，加上香港穩健的銀行體系，為保障香港的貨幣及金融穩定提供強而有力的後盾。

# 其他事務

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的貨幣發行委員會負責監察及探討與香港貨幣及金融穩定有關的課題。在2020年，貨幣發行委員會探討的課題包括香港經濟的情景分析、香港物業市場的評估、了解跨境資金流的概念架構，以及了解香港銀行同業市場。貨幣發行委員會會議紀錄及金管局向其呈交的貨幣發行局制度運作報告，均載於金管局網站。

# 貨幣研究

疫情持續下，香港貨幣及金融研究中心（研究中心）在2020年仍能維持一定數量的研究成果。在2020年，研究中心合共發表20篇研究論文，涵蓋貨幣政策、銀行體系穩定、市場微觀結構和金融科技發展等廣泛議題，部份論文已獲接納或正被評審在專業期刊中刊登。在疫情下由於要實施社交距離及旅遊限制，研究中心舉辦的研討會、講座及到訪研究計劃等主要活動需要押後，待日後公共衛生和旅遊條件回復正常後，研究中心將會復辦上述活動。

# 香港鈔票

繼於2020年1月推出20港元及50港元面額新鈔，2018年新鈔系列所有5款面額鈔票已在市面流通。該系列鈔票具備更強固及應用方便的防偽特徵，廣受市民歡迎，並逐漸取代舊版鈔票。

年內金管局繼續舉辦講座，介紹香港鈔票的設計及防偽特徵。金管局舉辦8場講座(包括網上形式)，增進公眾對香港鈔票的認識，吸引2,000多名人士參加，包括銀行櫃位職員、商戶及學生等。

# 硬幣收集計劃

硬幣收集計劃於2014年10月推出，年內繼續廣受大眾歡迎。這是全球首個有系統的流動硬幣收集計劃，設有兩部收銀車輪流停駐全港18區。每部收銀車均裝設兩部高速硬幣點算機，市民可選擇將硬幣轉換成鈔票或用作八達通卡或電子錢包等儲值支付工具增值，亦可將款項放入車內的公益金捐款箱。此外，金管局與香港社會服務聯會合作，在非政府組織賣旗日派出收銀車收集硬幣。收銀車亦到訪學校，增進學生對硬幣收集計劃的認識。過去多年硬幣收集計劃曾獲頒多個本港及國際獎項，對其創新及環保的處理方法予以肯定。

# Monetary Stability

Despite the uncertainties caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange and money markets have operated smoothly and in an orderly manner. Supported by substantial inflows of funds related to equities, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained generally strong for most of 2020, with the strong-side exchange rate guarantee being triggered multiple times. The linked exchange rate system is the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s financial system, fully demonstrating its strong resilience against shocks.

# Objective

The main objective of Hong Kong’s monetary policy is to maintain monetary stability, which means ensuring the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate, keeping the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar against the US dollar within the range of HK$7.75 to HK$7.85 per US dollar. This monetary system primarily employs a currency issuance bureau system, stipulating that the US dollar reserves held by the Exchange Fund must provide at least 100 percent support for the monetary base; if the monetary base changes, the US dollar reserves must also be adjusted accordingly, matching 100 percent of the changes in the monetary base.

The Monetary Base (Table 1) comprises:
- Certificates of Indebtedness (providing full backing for banknotes issued by the three note-issuing banks)
- Government-issued currency notes and coins
- The aggregate balances of clearing accounts maintained with the HKMA (i.e. total balances)
- Exchange Fund Bills and Bonds issued by the HKMA on behalf of the Government.

Table 1 Monetary Base

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through the automatic interest rate adjustment mechanism and its firm commitment to honoring exchange rate guarantees. When a strong (or weak) exchange rate guarantee is triggered, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, upon request from banks, will sell Hong Kong dollars and buy US dollars from banks at a rate of HK$7.75 per US dollar (or buy Hong Kong dollars and sell US dollars at a rate of HK$7.85), increasing (or decreasing) the aggregate balance, thereby lowering (or raising) Hong Kong dollar interest rates, and thus bringing the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate back within the exchange rate range of 7.75 to 7.85.

# 2020 Retrospective

# Exchange rate stability

With the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus in March, risk-aversion led global investors to increase their holdings of US dollars, tightening US dollar liquidity significantly. Under the Linked Exchange Rate System (LERS), Hong Kong dollar interest rates are influenced by corresponding US dollar interest rates, so the tightness of US dollar liquidity tightened Hong Kong's monetary conditions. Although the US Federal Reserve later implemented liquidity programs, easing US dollar funding pressures, Hong Kong's monetary conditions remained tight due to stock-related demand and end-of-quarter effects. The strong demand for Hong Kong dollars, combined with the positive interest rate differential between Hong Kong dollars and US dollars, stimulated carry trade activities, pushing the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate toward the strong-side exchange rate guarantee (Figure 1). The strong-side exchange rate guarantee was ultimately triggered in April. Subsequently, robust initial public offering fundraising activities, along with southbound capital flows under Stock Connects, drove stock-related capital inflows, keeping the Hong Kong dollar near the 7.75 level and causing the strong-side exchange rate guarantee to be triggered multiple times in 2020. The strong-side exchange rate guarantee was triggered a total of 85 times between April 21 and October 28, with cumulative capital inflows amounting to HK$383.5 billion. Overall, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange market operated normally throughout 2020.

Aggregate Balance before Discount Window and the total amount of outstanding foreign exchange fund notes and bonds increased from HKD 11,330 billion at the end of 2019 to HKD 15,266 billion at the end of 2020 (Figure 2). As the linked exchange rate assurance mechanism was triggered, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority sold a total of HKD 3,835 billion in response to bank requests. The COVID-19 pandemic led to volatility in the global macroeconomic environment, and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority gradually reduced the total amount of foreign exchange fund notes by HKD 200 billion in late April and early May to provide additional Hong Kong dollar liquidity. Due to the triggering of the linked exchange rate assurance mechanism and the reduction in the issuance of foreign exchange fund notes, Aggregate Balance before Discount Window increased from HKD 543 billion at the end of 2019 to HKD 4,575 billion at the end of 2020. The total amount of outstanding foreign exchange fund notes and bonds decreased slightly from HKD 10,787 billion to HKD 10,692 billion during the year, reflecting the reduction in the issuance of foreign exchange fund notes, which offset the interest on outstanding foreign exchange fund notes and bonds absorbed by newly issued foreign exchange fund notes and bonds in accordance with established practice. The overall monetary base continued to be fully supported by foreign exchange reserves.

# money markets

Following the decline in liquidity demand after the Lunar New Year holiday, Hong Kong interbank offered rates (HIBOR) generally fell in February (Figure 3). In March, due to dollar funding pressures, along with local factors such as new share capital raising and seasonal settlement demands, HIBOR temporarily rose. Subsequently, the activation of the strong exchange rate guarantee and reduced issuance of foreign exchange fund notes led to an increase in total reserves, gradually easing the Hong Kong dollar liquidity situation.

In response to the U.S. Federal Funds Rate target range being lowered twice in March, and reflecting year-end overnight and one-month Hong Kong bank interbank offered rates, the base rate decreased from 2.73% at the beginning of the year to a closing level of 0.50% at year-end. On the retail front, despite the lowering of the U.S. Federal Funds Rate target range, banks maintained their best lending rate unchanged. Overall, Hong Kong's money market continued to operate normally. Discount window borrowing fell from HKD 383 billion in 2019 to HKD 91 billion in 2020.

# Linked Exchange Rate System

For over 30 years, the Linked Exchange Rate System has been a crucial pillar of Hong Kong's financial system, consistently demonstrating strong resilience against challenges. In 2020, despite facing difficulties, the Hong Kong dollar's foreign exchange and money markets continued to operate normally, repeatedly proving the system's stability and effectiveness. During the year, some baseless rumors questioned the Linked Exchange Rate System and Hong Kong's financial stability. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) swiftly reiterated to the public that Hong Kong would continue to implement the Linked Exchange Rate System, emphasizing that the free flow of capital and the free convertibility of the Hong Kong dollar are protected under Article 112 of the Basic Law. The HKMA also published several articles explaining how Hong Kong's financial system continued to show strong resilience during challenging times. The government remains firmly committed to maintaining the Linked Exchange Rate System. The orderly operation of Hong Kong's financial markets and the continued normal use of the Hong Kong dollar as a medium of payment and store of value reflect the effectiveness of these measures in maintaining public confidence in the Linked Exchange Rate System. The International Monetary Fund reaffirmed in its External Sector Report 2020 that Hong Kong possesses transparent rules, ample fiscal and foreign exchange reserves, sound financial regulation and supervision, a flexible economy, and prudent fiscal structures, ensuring the credibility of the Linked Exchange Rate System.

A sound banking system plays a crucial role in the proper functioning of the exchange rate regime. Despite the negative impact of the coronavirus pandemic, the Hong Kong banking system has continued to operate smoothly, with liquidity and capital levels well above international standards. To ensure the banking system's ability to withstand shocks, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been closely monitoring banks' credit, liquidity, and interest rate risk management, as well as the results of stress tests, and maintaining regulation on bank lending. At the same time, the Authority has provided more liquidity to the banking system to maintain monetary and financial stability. In addition to reducing the issuance of Exchange Fund Notes to increase Hong Kong dollar liquidity, the Authority has established a series of liquidity facilities for banks. Furthermore, the Authority has maintained contact with banks to ensure they can utilize these liquidity facilities during periods of stress. In response to the volatility and uncertainties brought about by the coronavirus pandemic in global financial markets, the Authority has introduced temporary US dollar liquidity facilities to provide liquidity support to licensed banks, helping to alleviate the liquidity tightness in the global US dollar interbank lending market.

To enhance the transparency of the Monetary Authority's accounts, since October 1998, part of the Foreign Exchange Fund's assets have been designated for use as backing for the money supply. The Backing Ratio, which is the ratio of backing assets to the money supply, fluctuated between 109.8 and 112.1% in 2020, without reaching the upper or lower limits. The ratio closed at 109.9% on December 31 (Figure 4). Under the Linked Exchange Rate System, although certain assets of the Foreign Exchange Fund have been designated as part of the backing portfolio, all assets of the Foreign Exchange Fund can be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The substantial financial resources of the Foreign Exchange Fund, combined with the sound banking system in Hong Kong, provide a strong backing for the monetary and financial stability of Hong Kong.

# Other matters

The Currency Issuance Committee, under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, is responsible for monitoring and examining issues relating to Hong Kong’s currency and financial stability. In 2020, the topics explored by the Currency Issuance Committee included a scenario analysis of the Hong Kong economy, an assessment of the Hong Kong property market, understanding the conceptual framework of cross-border capital flows, and understanding the Hong Kong interbank market. The minutes of the Currency Issuance Committee meetings and the reports on the operation of the Currency Issuance System submitted by the HKMA to it are available on the HKMA website.

# Monetary research

Despite the ongoing pandemic, the Hong Kong Institute for Monetary and Financial Research (HKIMR) was still able to maintain a certain number of research outputs in 2020. In 2020, HKIMR published a total of 20 research papers, covering a wide range of topics including monetary policy, banking stability, market microstructure, and the development of financial technology. Some of these papers have been accepted or are being reviewed for publication in professional journals. Due to the need to implement social distancing and travel restrictions during the pandemic, major activities hosted by HKIMR, such as seminars, lectures, and research visits, had to be postponed. Once public health and travel conditions return to normal, HKIMR will resume these activities.

# Banknotes and coins

As of the end of 2020, the total value of banknotes in circulation (referring to banknotes issued by issuing banks) amounted to 559.5 billion Hong Kong dollars, representing an 8.3% increase compared to the previous year (Figures 5, 6, and 7). The total value of government-issued banknotes and coins in circulation was 12.7 billion Hong Kong dollars, a 0.6% decrease from the previous year (Figures 8 and 9). # Hong Kong Banknotes

Following the launch of the new $20 and $50 Hong Kong notes in January 2020, all five denominations of the 2018 series of notes are now in circulation. These notes feature more durable and user-friendly anti-counterfeiting features, are widely popular among the public, and are gradually replacing the older notes.

Throughout the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continued to hold seminars to introduce the design and anti-counterfeiting features of Hong Kong banknotes. The HKMA organized eight seminars (including online sessions), enhancing the public's understanding of Hong Kong banknotes and attracting more than 2,000 participants, including bank tellers, merchants, and students.

# Coin Collection Programme

The coin collection program was launched in October 2014 and remained popular throughout the year. It is the world's first systematic mobile coin collection initiative, featuring two coin collection vehicles that take turns stopping in all 18 districts across Hong Kong. Each vehicle is equipped with two high-speed coin counters, allowing citizens to choose to exchange coins for banknotes, or use them to top up stored-value payment tools such as Octopus cards or electronic wallets, or to donate the money into charity donation boxes inside the vehicles. In addition, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) collaborated with the Hong Kong Federation of Youth Groups to deploy the coin collection vehicles on non-governmental organization flag days to collect coins. The collection vehicles also visited schools to raise students' awareness of the coin collection program. Over the years, the coin collection program has received numerous local and international awards, recognizing its innovative and environmentally friendly approach.

# 銀行體系穩定

儘管新冠病毒疫情爆發為經濟帶來重大挑戰，香港銀行體系於2020年維持穩健。年內金管局除密切留意疫情對銀行營運及監管活動的影響並靈活應變外，繼續將監管重點放在認可機構的信用及流動性風險管理上。鑑於網絡威脅持續增加及銀行業使用金融科技的上升趨勢，金管局加強對認可機構科技風險管理及運作穩健性的監管。金管局亦與銀行及國際組織緊密合作，促進業界過渡至備用參考利率。

在操守監管方面，金管局給予認可機構在遵守監管規定上彈性處理的空間以及提供指引，以便一方面協助銀行在疫情下的業務運作及繼續為客戶提供服務，另一方面則繼續確保投資者及消費者得到保障。金管局聯同有關當局制定「跨境理財通」業務試點的建議實施細則，並諮詢業界。金管局與證券及期貨事務監察委員會合作，就精簡有關家族辦公室及擁有高資產淨值並精於財務事宜的投資者的銷售程序提供指引。此外，金管局加強對數碼金融服務消費者的保障，並繼續推動以客為本的企業文化。

在打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集方面，金管局迅速採取行動，不但釐清風險為本方法及科技如何協助認可機構更有效應對與新冠病毒疫情相關的情況，並同時審慎應對持續升溫的地緣政治緊張局勢對銀行體系造成的影響。金管局繼續支持有關提升打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集工作的成效與效率的措施，包括增加參與公私營夥伴共享訊息的認可機構數目，以及支持銀行業採用合規科技。金管局又順應科技及數據運用的國際發展趨勢，展開進一步加強打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集監察能力的計劃。

與此同時，金管局與銀行業緊密合作，優化監管政策與程序，以及推行提升人才專業能力的措施。香港在實施國際監管標準方面取得理想進展，包括資本充足標準和披露標準。在促進綠色及可持續銀行業的發展方面，金管局已進入三個階段中的第二階段，正制定相關監管規定。金管局亦繼續致力確保香港備有具公信力的認可機構處置機制，包括制定新處置標準及實施吸收虧損能力規定的規則，以提升認可機構的處置可行性。

# 目標

金管局的整體目標之一是促進銀行體系的安全及穩定。要達致這個目標，實有賴建立及維持具高度應對能力且能為香港經濟提供所需關鍵金融服務的金融體系。

銀行可能因營運方式，甚或在極端情況下因失序地倒閉而影響銀行體系的穩定。作為監管當局，金融管理專員在保障金融穩定方面擔當重要角色，確保銀行有能力抵禦衝擊、應對危機及自危機中恢復常態，以最終有助防止出現倒閉。金融管理專員負責對銀行進行審慎監管，以及認可香港的持牌銀行、有限制牌照銀行及接受存款公司（統稱「認可機構」）。金融管理專員亦負責某些金融市場基建的指定及監管。

然而，金融管理專員不能確保金融體系全無風險，香港的審慎監管制度亦並非為確保「零風險」而設。作為其中一個處置機制當局，金融管理專員力求確保一旦有認可機構不再可持續經營，能有秩序地處理其倒閉。為此，香港已設立金融機構處置機制，金融管理專員在該機制下為認可機構（以及其他類型機構）的處置機制當局。為落實香港的處置機制，必須制定處置規則及政策標準、進行處置規劃以排除認可機構處置可行性的障礙，以及建立金管局處置瀕臨倒閉認可機構的運作能力。為有效執行上述工作，金管局採納與國際一致及協調的方法。

# 2020年回顧

# 監管工作概覽

金管局在2020年共進行186次非現場審查，涵蓋範圍甚廣，包括認可機構的CAMEL評估、企業管治、風險管理及金融科技策略。為繼續加強認可機構的風險管治水平，金管局與認可機構董事局、獨立非執行董事或董事局轄下委員會共舉行30次會議，並與認可機構及其外聘核數師共舉行30次三方聯席會議。

除了非現場審查工作外，金管局亦進行定期現場審查，並以專題評估作為配合，以審視被評估屬較高風險的範疇。金管局於年內共進行610次現場審查及專題評估，並繼續以信用風險管理作為審查及評估的主要重點之一。另一個重點是在新冠病毒疫情下的業務操作風險及科技風險管理。此外，金管局又增加針對流動性及市場風險管理的現場審查及專題評估次數。同時，專項審查小組亦對認可機構的證券、投資產品、保險及強制性公積金（強積金）相關業務進行現場審查及專題評估。

儘管面對疫情，金管局維持監管力度，並作出彈性安排，靈活有效地履行監管職責，包括在提交申報表及進行現場審查方面給予彈性處理的空間；加強數據收集以補足現場審查，以及利用網上會議平台。

# 紓緩客戶資金周轉壓力的措施

因應新冠病毒疫情爆發，金管局於2019年10月成立的銀行業中小企貸款協調機制（協調機制）推出多輪協助企業及個人客戶的紓緩措施，鼓勵銀行在審慎風險管理原則容許下繼續支持借款人的融資需要。其中最主要的是協調機制於5月推出的「預先批核還息不還本」計劃。計劃下合資格的企業客戶的所有貸款本金還款可延期6個月。該計劃在11月延長6個月後，在2021年3月再度延長6個月至10月底。該計劃約有100間銀行參與，覆蓋12萬合資格企業客戶。截至12月底，銀行共批出58,000多宗企業客戶貸款展期及其他支援措施的個案，涉及金額超過7,400億港元。個人客戶方面，銀行亦推出住宅按揭「還息不還本」計劃，「居者有其屋計劃」下資助房屋的相關按揭亦涵蓋在內。此外，銀行亦提供應急貸款予從事受疫情嚴重打擊行業的客戶、延長個人貸款期限，以及下調各種個人信貸的收費。截至12月底，銀行共批出28,000多宗住宅按揭「還息不還本」及其他個人應急貸款的個案，涉及金額超過440億港元。

# 物業按揭貸款

金管局自2009年起先後推出多輪逆周期宏觀審慎監管措施，已經加強銀行的風險管理及香港銀行體系應對本港樓市一旦突然逆轉的抵禦能力。新批出住宅按揭貸款的平均按揭成數於2020年12月為57%，而有關按揭成數於2009年9月推出首輪逆周期措施前為64%。2020年新批出住宅按揭貸款的平均按揭成數有所上升，主要由於當中涉及按揭保險的貸款的佔比有所增加，而這類貸款的按揭成數一般較高。新批出按揭的平均供款與入息比率亦維持在低水平，於12月為37%，而在2010年8月首度推出有關比率上限時為41%（圖1）。

考慮到非住宅物業的價格走勢與交投量、經濟基調及外圍環境等因素，金管局在8月放寬非住宅物業按揭貸款的逆周期宏觀審慎監管措施，將這類貸款的適用按揭成數上限上調10個百分點，一般個案的上限由四成上調至五成。

# 業務操作及科技風險的監管

因應2020年初爆發新冠病毒疫情，金管局採取連串措施減低疫情對銀行業務運作的影響。有關措施包括要求認可機構檢討其持續業務運作計劃，並採取適當的預防措施，以保障員工與客戶的健康，以及維持重要銀行服務。此外，金管局提醒認可機構加強與員工及客戶的溝通，就其處所可能出現確診個案的情況作好準備，以及制定應對較為嚴峻但可能發生的風險情境的持續業務運作計劃。金管局與業界保持緊密聯繫，又要求認可機構保持警覺，並因應疫情的最新發展及政府的社交距離措施，不時審視其持續業務運作計劃。

金管局完成對「網絡防衛計劃」的全面檢討及廣泛的業界諮詢後，於11月推出「網絡防衛計劃2.0」，因應海外網絡風險管理的最新做法，進一步提升「網絡防衛計劃」。當中「網絡防衛評估框架」加入了有關網絡事故應對及恢復的最新國際穩健做法。「網絡防衛計劃」下的「專業培訓計劃」方面，資歷認證清單的範圍有所擴大，納入主要海外地區的同等資歷。金管局又向香港銀行公會（銀行公會）提出多項建議，令「網絡風險資訊共享平台」更易於使用。「網絡防衛計劃2.0」於2021年1月1日生效。

# 智慧銀行

經過在「金融科技監管沙盒」進行嚴謹的測試與試行後，所有在2019年獲發銀行牌照的8間虛擬銀行都已經於年內開業。虛擬銀行運用創新科技，提供全新的客戶體驗，例如利用大數據分析進行中小企貸款的信貸評估，以加快貸款批核程序。為加強客戶參與及建立客戶對品牌的忠誠，部分虛擬銀行更在其定期存款及獎賞計劃等服務中加入遊戲元素。

# 流動性及市場風險的監管

金管局在4月推出一系列措施，確保銀行同業市場及銀行體系在疫情下繼續暢順運作。這些措施包括釐清「金管局流動資金安排」的操作細則及推出臨時美元流動資金安排，並重申在監管架構下認可機構可使用流動性緩衝的彈性。金管局又與認可機構進行演習，確保認可機構已經作好準備，能夠在有需要時運用這些措施。
